III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Sufficiency of staff.
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126
Section (1) The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
Description supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty to
perform the prescribed functions required by these administrative
rules and in the agency’s program statement and to provide for the
continual needs, protection, and supervision of residents
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 6/16/24, youth was escalated and threatened to harm herself.
Staff member exited the pod to call for assistance while another
staff member stayed inside the pod. Youth found a part of a
cabinet and used it to repeatedly harm herself. Staff member did
not intervene and instead moved a TV out of the pod.
Investigation Interviews:
Therapist was interviewed via phone on June 17, 2024. Therapist
reported she is Youth A’s direct therapist at the facility and was an
on-call therapist on June 16, 2024. She reported she received a call
from Staff 2 around 3:45pm that Youth A was in a restraint due to
head banging concerns and was put on increased five-to-ten-minute
checks. Therapist reported she received a second call from Staff 2,
around 6:45pm on June 16, 2024, of the concerns of Staff 1 not
intervening when Youth A was cutting herself. It was reported Staff 2
was trying to de-escalate Youth A’s behaviors and Staff 1 was doing
checks on the youth. When the situation became dangerous, Staff 2
asked Staff 1 to call for support but Staff 1 continued to sit in a chair
doing checks and did not help with the situation. Staff 2 had to run off
the unit to make a call for support when she came back Youth A was
cutting her arm and Staff 1 was rolling the TV away. Therapist
reported when she spoke to Staff 1, Staff 1 reported when she tried
to do a check-in and intervene in Youth A’s behaviors earlier that
day, Youth A told her to shut up and leave her alone. Staff 1 reported
to Therapist Staff 2 then took over verbally de-escalating Youth A
while Staff 1 completed the other checks on the unit to help decrease
the behavior. Therapist reported Youth B was playing video games
2

on the unit during this situation and the other youth were off the
unit. Therapist reported Staff 1 told her she moved the TV off the
unit because Youth A was walking behind it and appeared to be
looking for something to self-harm with. Youth A broke off part of the
cabinet to self-harm with, but staff were able to get the pieces away
from her without physical restraint. Nurse was able to look at the cuts
and clean them up without requiring stitches. Therapist reported
Youth A does not have any supplemental safety plan and just had
increased checks added due to her head banging earlier that day.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on June 18,
2024, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Youth A reported
early on June 16, 2024, she was put into a restraint due to banging
her head to harm herself. She reported she was upset because
Youth C was in the hospital and believed it was her fault because
they were playing gymnastics and Youth C hurt her head. Youth A
reported later that day she was still thinking about Youth C, so she
started to pace around the milieu to look for something to harm
herself with. She reported she remembered Staff 2 being present but
does not fully remember Staff 1 being there. Youth A reported later in
the interview she remembered Staff 1 sitting in the green chair in the
milieu not doing anything. She reported Staff 2 followed Youth A
around the milieu and kept telling her to stop her behavior. Youth A
reported she broke off a piece of the counter and started to cut her
forearm. She reported she remembered the TV on the unit was
moved because she was going to harm herself with the cord but
does not remember who moved the TV. Youth A reported she
remembered Staff 2 calling for additional support. She reported she
does not remember Staff 1 saying anything to her and does not
believe Youth B was in the milieu at the time. Youth A reported she
told Staff 1 to get away from her but that was after the restraint
occurred earlier that day. She reported she felt Staff 1 was not
supportive during the situation because she was just sitting in the
green chair. Youth A reported Nurse, Staff 2, and Staff 3 were able to
get the piece of countertop away from her by verbal coaching and
Nurse checked her cuts on her forearms.
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on June 18,
2024, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Staff 1 reported she
has been working at the facility for three months. She reported she
does not work much on Youth A’s unit because Youth C reported
Staff 1 reminds her of a former staff from another facility that caused
her trauma. On June 16, 2024, she was working on Youth A’s unit
and was involved in the restraint earlier that day due to Youth A's
head banging. Staff 1 reported she was only involved with switching
out with another staff and Youth A did not say anything to her. Later
that evening, Staff 1 completed a room check and Youth A was
playing in her room. She stated less than five minutes later, Youth A
3

came out of her room and continued to pace around the milieu.
During this time, Youth B was playing video games and Staff 2 was
in charge of checks. She reported Staff 2 gave Staff 1 the checks to
complete so she could do the de-escalation with Youth A. Staff 1
reported Staff 2 told her to use her walkie-talkie to call over to the
other unit for support and Staff 1 completed this. She reported that
no one responded to the call since that unit was outside. Staff 1
reported Staff 2 continued to verbally de-escalate Youth A and she
continued to pick at the counter to get a piece to self-harm. Staff 1
reported the only thing she told Youth A was, “You do not want to
add property destruction to your reflection sheet.” Youth A told Staff 1
to shut up. Staff 1 reported within training she was taught if a youth
does not respond to the first redirection, to let her be. She reported
she was also trained within behavior management training that one
staff should only be speaking to the youth that is escalated, so that is
why Staff 1 let Staff 2 take that role. Staff 1 reported she sat next to
Youth B while he continued to play his video games. She reported
she attempted to get Youth B to leave the area, but he refused and
wanted to continue to play his game. Staff 1 reported when Youth A
began to cut herself with the piece of the counter, Staff 2 made a call
for a show of support, and Staff 1 moved the TV since Youth A was
looking for more items to harm herself with. Staff 1 reported she
continued to sit down next to Youth B when Nurse and Staff 3
showed up for support. She reported the whole situation lasted less
than ten minutes. Staff 1 reported Staff 2 was doing a good job with
trying to redirect Youth A. She reported the only thing that should
have been done differently was a show of support should have been
called quicker, as they waited a few minutes for the other unit to get
back to them. Staff 1 reported she also thought about how she
should have not sat down with Youth B when Staff 3 and Nurse
showed up because it looked like she was not doing anything. She
reported she was trying to verbally de-escalate but Youth A told her
to shut up and she helped clear out the area. Staff 1 reported she
was trying to maintain support for Youth B.
Staff 2 was interviewed via phone on June 18, 2024, in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Staff 2 reported she had been
working at the facility for one month. She reported on June 16, 2024,
Youth A had been struggling with self-harm. Staff 2 reported she told
Staff 1 to complete a check on Youth A and then Youth A came out
of her room. She reported Youth A started to pace in the milieu and
tried to break things off the wall and counter to self-harm. Staff 2
reported Staff 1 attempted to redirect Youth A but Youth A told Staff
1 to shut up. She reported she heard Staff 1 say to Youth A, “You
don’t want to add property destruction to your list.” This made Youth
A more frustrated, and Staff 1 then sat down in a chair. Staff 2 told
Staff 1 to call over the walkie-talkie to the other unit to get support,
which she did. They waited five minutes, but no one responded, and
4

Youth A continued to try to harm herself. She reported they started to
clear off the unit and Youth A continued to pace around. Staff 2
reported she told Staff 1 that a show of support needed to be called
but Staff 1 did not get up from her chair to make the call, so Staff 2
followed through with that action. She reported when came back,
Staff 1 had moved the TV off the unit but that was all she did. Staff 2
reported Youth B was on the unit and Staff 1 was sitting next to him.
She reported she does not know if Staff 1 asked Youth B to go to his
room, but she should have done that. Staff 2 reported Staff 3 and
Nurse showed up for support to help Youth A calm down. She
reported she was frustrated with Staff 1 because she did not get up
to make the phone call for the show of support and does not believe
she asked Youth B to go to his room. Staff 2 reported if Youth B had
gone to his room, then she could have had support from Staff 1 to
help with Youth A.
Youth B was interviewed face to face at the facility on June 18,
2024, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Youth B reported Staff
1 is a good staff and was proving him support during the day Youth A
was self-harming. He reported Staff 1 asked him to go to his room,
but he did not want to because he wanted to play video games.
Youth B reported staff cannot force a youth to go to their room. He
reported Staff 1 attempted to verbally de-escalate Youth A, but she
told her to “fuck off”.
Supervisor was interviewed via phone on July 8, 2024, in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Supervisor reported she
responded to the code call to provide support on the unit. She
reported when she arrived Staff 1 was sitting with Youth B and Staff
2 was following Youth A around the unit telling her to stop trying to
harm herself. She reported she focused on Youth A to process the
situation and redirected her question by asking her why she was
hurting herself. Supervisor reported she was able to verbally de-
escalate Youth A. She reported Staff 1 did appear to have eyes on
the situation but was not interacting with Youth A when Supervisor
was present. Supervisor reported the only thing she would have
changed about the situation was to not have Staff 1 sitting down but
have her stand near Youth B as more of a shield in case Youth A
came after Youth B. She reported she did speak with Staff 1 after the
incident deescalated and Staff 1 reported she did not engage with
Youth A because Youth A told her to leave her alone and she did not
want to escalate Youth A more, so she allowed Staff 2 to take over
that de-escalation.
Staff 3 was interviewed via phone on July 8, 2024, in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Staff 3 reported he responded
to the code call to support Staff 1 and Staff 2 with Youth A. He
reported when he arrived Staff 2 was following Youth A around trying
5

to calm her down. Staff 3 reported Staff 1 was sitting with Youth B
and completing the required unit checks. He reported he did not have
concerns with the situation as Staff 1 was sitting with Youth B. Staff 3
reported he does work with Staff 1 frequently and reported she does
a good job with working with the youth on the unit.
Nurse was interviewed via phone on July 8, 2024, in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Nurse reported she does not
remember the details exactly as she was more focused on making
sure Youth A was medically safe. She reported she does not
remember which staff were involved in this situation.
Documents reviewed:
- Facility’s Behavior Management Policy- This policy notes
staff are to use the less restrictive measures when there is
escalated behaviors. Staff should offer options/ coping skills,
offer other spaces the youth can go to, and utilize behavioral
momentum.
- Staff 1’s Personnel File- Staff 1 has no disciplinary actions
within his file. Staff 1 is up to date on all required trainings.
She completed restraint model training on March 27, 2024,
and completed the behavior management training on April 5,
2024.
- Incident Reports dated June 16, 2024- Three separate
incident reports completed by Staff 1, Staff 2, and Supervisor
about the actions that took placed with Youth A causing self-
harm to herself and a code call being made. Staff 1’s incident
reported was consistent with Staff 1’s interview. Staff 2’s
incident reported was consistent with Staff 2’ interview.
Supervisor’s incident reported was consistent with
Supervisor’s interview.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as per staff and youth
interviews, Staff 1 was caring for the needs of Youth B and
following the direction of the policy during a crisis situation.
Technical Assistance:
Technical assistance was offered to the facility about refreshing
staff on the importance of clear communication and roles during a
crisis situation. It was also recommended for staffing units to
review the experience of staff on shift, during this event there was
two staff present that had less than four months of experience.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
6

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
